Scheme 1 Coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Cooperative effects for the activation and ring-opening of epoxide. Conditions: PO 2.0g, catalyst 0.1g, 130°C, 3MPa, 12h; (B) FT-IR spectra (C) TGA curves of fresh and recycled NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 (0.12) catalyst after five reuses. Design of bifunctional NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 single-component heterogeneous catalyst for chemical fixation of carbon dioxide to cyclic carbonates Mengshuai Liu b Bo Liu b Lin Liang c Fangxiao Wang b Lei Shi b Jianmin Sun a b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150080, PR China State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin 150080 PR China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150080, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin 150080 PR China c School of Life Science and Technology, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150080, PR China School of Life Science and Technology Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin 150080 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150080, PR China. State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment Harbin Institute of Technology Harbin 150080 PR China Graphical abstract The novel bifunctional Zn/SBA-15 supported ammonium salt (NH3I-Zn/SBA-15) as single-component heterogeneous catalyst for the coupling of CO2 with epoxides was developed. FT-IR, XRD, N2 adsorption/desorption, TEM, XPS techniques were used to determine the morphological structure and physicochemical properties of NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 sample. The catalyst exhibited exceptionally effective activity with 93% yield and 99% selectivity and a high TOF of 306h−1 to propylene carbonate at 130°C and 3MPa of CO2 for 12h in the absence of cocatalyst and solvent participation. Also the catalytic system was versatile to the cycloadditions of other epoxides with CO2 under the optimized reaction conditions. Additionally, the catalyst was easily recycled and reused only with slight loss of activity after five recycles. Besides, a possible catalytic mechanism involving cooperative activation of epoxide and ring-opening by one-component and bifunctional catalyst was proposed. The protocol herein provides important insights on design of novel single-component heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 relevant transformations. Keywords Carbon dioxide NH2-Zn/SBA-15 Protonation Heterogeneous Cyclic carbonate 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide has been in the spotlight as a renewable C1 feedstock because it is abundant, readily available and non-poisonous, whereas the scope of the synthetic applications of CO2 is limited due to its low reactivity [1,2]. The development of efficient synthetic methods for CO2 fixation is therefore an important and challenging subject [3]. Specifically, cyclic carbonates are valuable synthetic targets, which can be obtained through the coupling reaction between CO2 and epoxides via 100% atom economy (Scheme 1 ). Also cyclic carbonates are widely used as polar solvents, electrolytes in lithium secondary batteries, precursors for synthesizing polycarbonates and polyurethanes, intermediates for production of pharmaceuticals and agricultural chemicals [3–5]. Recently, large amounts of catalysts for cyclic carbonate synthesis have been developed, including metal oxide [6], metal salen complexes [7], metal-organic framework [8], functional polymers [9] and various ionic liquids (ILs) etc [10–14]. And the pioneering work has demonstrated that a certain amount of cocatalyst (e.g., hydrogen bond donors, ZnI2, ZnBr2, Bu4NBr, Bu4NI, KI) [7,13,15,16], which acted as Lewis acid for activating epoxide or nucleophile for ring-opening of the epoxide, is also necessarily needed (Scheme 2 ) when bare ionic liquid was used as catalyst, but the leaching problem of cocatalyst/nucleophile and complex catalytic system are unsatisfactory to the practical applications. To address this issue, numerous task-specific ILs and supported ILs able to mediate this reaction have emerged, nevertheless, most of the reported IL catalysts suffered from time-consuming preparation, costly raw materials requirement, tough experimental conditions and purification procedure. Recently, Ema et al. [17] employed single-component bifunctional ZnII or MgII porphyrin catalysts, which also bear quaternary phosphonium or ammonium bromide as nucleophilic group with different alkyl chain lengths, showed remarkably high catalytic activity towards CO2 cycloaddition to epoxyhexane with TOF at 19,000h−1, but this homogeneous catalyst must face the crucial problems of the catalyst separation and recycling. Baj et al. [18] grafted quaternary ammonium chlorides on heterogeneous multi-walled carbon nanotubes and investigated the catalytic performance for synthesis of various cyclic carbonates. By the synergistic effects of ammonium halide and carboxyl moiety grafted on carbon nanotubes, the different product yields varied between 7 and 89%, and the catalytic activity needed to be further improved. Hence, it is still a challenge to develop highly efficient, single-component and reusable heterogeneous catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 to epoxides. In our previous work, we explored that Zn/SBA-15 coupled with DMF were highly effective catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene oxide and in the catalytic process the loaded zinc active site as Lewis acid activated epoxide and DMF acted as cocatalyst to activate CO2 for further conversion [19]. However, the developed binary Zn loaded SBA-15/DMF catalysts also existed the problems of cocatalyst necessary and leaching problem as well as complex catalytic system. As a continuous work and inspired by the pioneering work of Ema et al. [17] and Baj et al. [18], amine-modified Zn/SBA-15 catalysts with different Zn/Si molar ratios were designed and prepared by 3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) functionalization. Furthermore, in order to improve the catalytic performance of the one-component catalyst on the coupling reaction of epoxide and CO2, the nucleophilic group (such as Br−, I−) was introduced via protonating NH2-Zn/SBA-15 for facilitating ring-opening of epoxide. Additionally, various analytical technologies were fully characterized the catalyst structure. The proposed one-component catalyst with bifunctional groups of Zn site and I− anion would be an efficient alternative to solve the need and leaching problems of cocatalyst. Additionally, the effects of Zn/Si molar ratio as well as reaction parameters such as initial CO2 pressure, reaction temperature and reaction time on catalytic activity were investigated thoroughly. The reusability of the catalytic system was investigated and the possible synergistic catalytic mechanism was proposed that the one-component catalyst integrately combined Lewis acid site and nucleophilic group, which acted as activator for the epoxide and favored the subsequent ring-opening of the epoxide by nucleophile. 2 Experimental 2.1 General information Carbon dioxide with 99.99% purity was purchased from Harbin Qinghua Industrial gases Co., Ltd. PEO20-PPO70-PEO20 (P123) and other epoxides except propylene oxide (PO) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Co. 3-Aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES), tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS), hydrochloric acid (36–38%), hydrobromic acid (40%), hydroiodic acid (45%) and acetic acid (98%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Propylene oxide and other chemicals were provided by Beijing InnoChem Science & Technology Co., Ltd. with analytical purity and used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of the catalyst Zn/SBA-15 samples were prepared according to the published literature [19,20]. Typically, 2.0g of triblock copolymer P123 and stoichiometric ratio of zinc nitrate were dissolved into 75mL 1.6M HCl, then 4.25g of TEOS was added and stirred for 24h at 40°C. Thereafter, the resultant solution was transferred into the autoclave and heated at 100°C for another 24h under static condition. Finally, the mixture was evaporated with stirring at 80°C and calcined at 550°C in air with a heating rate of 1°Cmin−1 for 6h. The obtained sample was denoted as Zn/SBA-15 (X), where X represented Zn/Si molar ratio. APTES-functionalized Zn/SBA-15 samples were synthesized as follows [21]. 0.5g Zn/SBA-15 was dispersed in 50mL dry toluene and then 5mL APTES was added slowly into the flask, the reaction mixture was stirred at 80°C for 16h. The solid product was isolated via filtration, washed with ethanol and dried at 80°C over 12h under vacuum. The obtained sample was denoted as NH2-Zn/SBA-15 (X). Different NH3L-Zn/SBA-15 (L=Cl, Br, I, CH3COO) were prepared by protonating NH2-Zn/SBA-15 with the corresponding protonic acid (e.g., HCl, HBr, HI, CH3COOH). Typically, excess HI aqueous solution was slowly dripped into 0.5g NH2-Zn/SBA-15 and stirred for 12h at ambient temperature with light blocked. Then the solid product was isolated via filtration, washed with ethanol and dried under vacuum at 80°C over 12h. The obtained sample was denoted as NH3I-Zn/SBA-15(X). 2.3 Characterization FT-IR spectra were measured on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 FT-IR Spectrometer with anhydrous KBr discs. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (40kV, 40mA) for phase identification. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were collected at −196°C using a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 system. Samples were evacuated at 150°C for 12h in the degas port of the adsorption analyzer. The surface area was calculated using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, the pore size distribution was derived from the desorption branch of the isotherms based on the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model and total pore volume was determined from the amount of the nitrogen adsorbed at P/P0 ca. 0.99. In transmission electron microscopes (TEM) measurements, the specimens were dispersed in ethanol and placed on holey copper grids, tests were conducted on Tecnai G2 Spirit with operation voltage of 120kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were recorded on a Thermo Fisher Scientific Escalab 250Xi. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using NETZSCH STA 449F3 simultaneous thermogravimetric analyzer under N2 atmosphere in the temperature range from room temperature to 800°C with the heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. GC analyses were performed on Agilent GC-7890A equipped with capillary column (Agilent 19091J-413) using a flame ionization detector. 2.4 Catalytic cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides All the cycloaddition reactions were carried out in a 50mL high-pressure stainless steel reactor. Typically, the reactor was firstly purged with CO2 to evacuate air, then the catalyst (0.1g) and PO (2.0g, 34.5mmol) were charged into the reactor successively. Subsequently, CO2 was injected up to desired pressure and the reactor was heated to the required temperature for a designated period of time. After the completion of the reaction, the reactor was cooled to 0°C in ice-water bath and depressurized to an atmospheric pressure slowly. The products were analyzed on GC, and the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, washed with ethyl acetate, then dried under vacuum and reused directly for the next run. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 samples The physicochemical properties of amine modified NH2-Zn/SBA-15 samples with various Zn/Si molar ratio before and after protonation were systematically characterized by FT-IR, XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption and XPS technique as depicted in Supporting Information (Figs. S1–S4), which successfully identified the catalyst structure. Table 1 showed the morphological properties of SBA-15, NH2-Zn/SBA-15 and NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 samples, the pore volume and pore diameter decreased gradually with APTES-functionalization and subsequent protonation, which were attributed to the dispersions of alkyl-NH2 and −NH3I species on the internal pores of SBA-15 and partially blocked the pore structure [22]. The BET surface of NH2-Zn/SBA-15 (0.12) was much lower than SBA-15, also the surface of NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 (0.12) further reduced to 282m2/g after protonation by HI. Similar decrease trends were observed obviously in the pore size and pore volume due to the introductions of alkyl-NH2 and HI species. The structures of the synthesized SBA-15, NH2-Zn/SBA-15 and NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 were further confirmed by TEM technique (Fig. 1 ). The mesostructures were well preserved in these samples, consistent with the results of XRD and N2 adsorption. The enhanced roughness of the long-range channel in NH2-Zn/SBA-15 and NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 samples successfully demonstrated the APTES-functionalization and protonation. 3.2 Screening of catalysts The catalytic activities of bifunctional NH2-Zn/SBA-15 samples with various Zn/Si molar ratio as well as different protonating agents were tested on the reaction of PO and CO2, the results were summarized in Table 2 . Neither SBA-15 nor Zn/SBA-15 showed a satisfactory catalytic activity (entry 1 and 2). While the amine-modified Zn/SBA-15 catalyst exhibited moderate catalytic activity for PC synthesis (entry 3), which was resulted from the synergistic effects of acidic Zn site effectively activating the epoxide and basic amino groups activating CO2. Correspondingly, Zn/SBA-15 supported ammonium salts were developed to improve the catalytic activity remarkably (entries 4–6). Notably, the catalyst at Zn/Si ratio of 0.12 showed the best activity with 80% PC yield under cocatalyst- and solvent- free conditions of 150°C and 3.0MPa CO2 for 12h. Additionally, the effects of different protonating agents on PC yield were discussed (entries 5, 7–9), when HI was used as protonated acid, almost quantitative conversion and 99% PC yield could be obtained with high TOF of 326h−1 (entry 9). This was attributed to the synergetic effects coming from doped Zn and stronger nucleophilic I− anion, which accelerated the activation and ring-opening of PO thus promoted the reaction smoothly. Meantime, the catalytic activity decreased in the order of NH3I-Zn/SBA-15>NH3Br-Zn/SBA-15>NH3Cl-Zn/SBA-15>NH3CH3COO-Zn/SBA-15 with the same Zn/Si ratio, consistent with the nucleophilic ability of the anions, displaying the importance of nucleophilic attack. 3.3 Influence of reaction parameters The influence of reaction parameters on the catalytic activity over NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 (0.12) was depicted in Fig. 2 . The temperature had a pronounced positive effect on the coupling reaction from 110 to 150°C, correspondingly, the PC yield was enhanced significantly from 56% to 99% (Fig. 2A), as the elevated temperature facilitated the effective collisions between the active species of catalyst and the substrate molecules [23]. Practically, CO2 cycloaddition is highly exothermic and effective heat removal is crucial to save energy. In order to recovery of the reaction heat as steam, the reaction temperature around 130°C would be desirable, and lower reaction temperature will result in low heat exchange efficiency [24], and higher temperature will cause energy consumption. The effect of initial CO2 pressure on PC yield was investigated as shown in Fig. 2B, a dramatic rise of PC yield was obtained in the low-pressure range of 1.0–3.0MPa, whereas, the further increase of CO2 pressure from 3.0MPa to 5.0MPa led to slight decrease in product yield. The phenomenon was caused by the concentration variations of CO2 and PO in the phases of CO2-PO system [25]. When the initial CO2 pressure further increased beyond 3.0MPa, more PO was extracted into the gas phase, which caused the reduction of PO concentration in the vicinity of the catalyst in the liquid phase, leading to the decrease in PC product. Additionally, the effect of reaction time on PC synthesis was provided in Fig. 2C. The cycloaddition reaction proceeded rapidly to 93% PC yield within the first 12h. Further prolonging the reaction time resulted in only a slight rise in PC yield, so 12h was the optimal reaction time. 3.4 Effects of water The effect of water on the model reaction of CO2 cycloaddition to PO was also studied as water is inevitable in real gas [26]. As shown in Fig. 3 , 69% PC yield with 99% selectivity was obtained over NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 (0.12) catalyst under employed reaction conditions in the absence of water. With water introduced, the PC yield increased smoothly with H2O/PO molar ratio rising to 0.05, the phenomenon is because H2O as the hydrogen bond donor can assist the smooth ring-opening of epoxide by forming hydrogen bonds with the oxygen atom of PO [27]. However, there appeared a decrease in PC yield with further increase H2O/PO molar ratio, which was resulted from the adsorption of excess water could cover the active sites of the catalyst. Hence, the catalyst was permissible for CO2 conversion in the presence of moderate amount of moisture. 3.5 Catalyst recycling The reusability of a catalyst plays an important role in practical application. As shown in Fig. 4A , the recycling experiments were tested by conducting the reaction at the optimized reaction conditions, i.e. 130°C and 3MPa CO2 and 12h. There was no significant change of PC yield across the first two runs, whereas a slight reduction was found at the next three runs. By analyzing the FT-IR spectra of the spent NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 (0.12) catalyst (Fig. 4B), there appeared an obvious new band at ca. 1719.1cm−1, which was ascribed to CO of formed carbonate [28], and the strong absorption peak of −NH3 + at ca. 1617cm−1 [29] was obviously weakened. Moreover, from TGA curves in Fig. 4C, a slight weight loss of 2wt%–3wt% was observed below 300°C for fresh catalyst, as the result of decomposition of amine groups on the surface, which was in agreement with the calculation result of the N content analysis, at 2.73% (Table S1). Compared with the fresh catalyst, the weight loss initially appeared in the temperature range of 205°C to 300°C for spent catalyst, which was resulted from the concomitant decomposition of PC product, and the decomposition rate obviously decreased in the temperature range of 300°C to 500°C due to the partial leaching of alkyl ammonium cations, which was also verified by the disappearance of Si-C stretching at 933cm−1 in FTIR spectra of the spent catalyst (Fig. 4B) [30]. And the recycled catalyst appeared significantly higher weight loss above 500°C, possibly due to the partial structural collapse after five times reuse. Hence, the coverage of NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 by the high-boiling PC residue and partial leaching of alkyl ammonium cations as well as the structural collapse with recyclings prevented or reduced the catalytic active sites, thus reduced the PC yield. 3.6 Cycloaddition of CO2 with various epoxides The versatile scopes of NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 (0.12) for the reactions of various epoxides with CO2 were examined under the optimized reaction conditions (Table 3 ). All terminal epoxides with both electron-withdrawing and electron-donating substituents could be smoothly converted to the corresponding carbonate products, and gave good to excellent yields and selectivities (entries 1–4). However, the internal epoxide such as cyclohexene oxide exhibited relatively low activity even though prolonging the reaction time to 18h (entry 5), which was presumably resulted from the steric hindrance that obstructed the nucleophilic attack and the subsequent cycloaddition step. 3.7 Possible mechanism According to the experimental results and pioneering work [31–34], the plausible mechanism for the CO2 cycloaddition to epoxide over NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 catalyst was proposed in Scheme 3 . Firstly, the Lewis acidic zinc site bonded to the oxide atom of epoxide through the formation of zinc-epoxide adduct to realize polarization of CO bond (Step 1), which had a positive effect on the ring opening of epoxide. Then I− anion synergistically attacked on the less sterically hindered β-carbon atom of epoxide assisting the ring-opening to form the oxyanion intermediate (Step 2). It was generally recognized that ring-opening of epoxide was the rate-determining step for the whole CO2 cycloaddition reaction [35]. Thereafter, CO2 inserted into the intermediate producing the new alkyl carbonate compound (Step 3), which eventually afforded the cyclic carbonate and regenerated the catalyst by the subsequent intramolecular ring-closure (Step 4). Hence, the cooperative activation of epoxide by Lewis acid Zn and ring-opening of oxirane by nucleophilic I−, which were provided by one-component bifunctional catalyst, favored the cycloaddition reaction smoothly. 4 Conclusions A novel bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst for CO2 cycloaddition to epoxides with excellent activity and selectivity was designed. The developed one-component catalyst could realize the synthesis of various cyclic carbonates under solvent- and cocatalyst- free conditions due to the synergetic effects involving Lewis acidic site and nucleophilic anion. And it was permissible for CO2 conversion with a moderate amount of moisture. Also the catalyst could be reused only with slight loss of activity after five recycles. Compared with the previous heterogeneous catalysts, the catalytic system used in this study was one-component, bifunctional, solvent- and cocatlyst- free. The developed efficient catalyst provides an insight into design of newly heterogeneous catalysts for the practical applications in relevant CO2 conversion. IBRSEM. 201327). Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.molcata.2016.03.037. FT-IR, XRD, N2 adsorption/desorption, TEM, XPS techniques were used to determine the morphological structure and physicochemical properties of NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 sample. The catalyst exhibited exceptionally effective activity with 93% yield and 99% selectivity and a high TOF of 306h−1 to propylene carbonate at 130°C and 3MPa of CO2 for 12h in the absence of cocatalyst and solvent participation. Also the catalytic system was versatile to the cycloadditions of other epoxides with CO2 under the optimized reaction conditions. Additionally, the catalyst was easily recycled and reused only with slight loss of activity after five recycles. Besides, a possible catalytic mechanism involving cooperative activation of epoxide and ring-opening by one-component and bifunctional catalyst was proposed. The protocol herein provides important insights on design of novel single-component heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 relevant transformations.
coredata.dc:title: Design of bifunctional NH3I-Zn/SBA-15 single-component heterogeneous catalyst for chemical fixation of carbon dioxide to cyclic carbonates
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
